concern: I'm in a MA program right now and we just started in-person learning. Until this week, I had been at my parents' house doing online school from there. While I'm definitely not the biggest proponent of online school, I was actually really enjoying life at home. I got to focus on doing readings and work without worrying about maintaining my own living space, I didn't have a commute to and from classes, and I really enjoyed hanging out with my family every day. Now I'm in a different city which is still pretty shut down from the pandemic, living alone, I can't see anyone, I haven't been able to focus on my coursework that much, and I just feel really *lonely* especially since the people in my cohort aren't keen on getting together due to the pandemic. Even though I absolutely love my program and what I'm studying, I'm starting to question if it's worth the lifestyle choices that are necessary (e.g., moving away from home, the job search being global rather than local). Now, I'm finding myself wishing the weeks would pass until I can go back during the break. I'm wondering if anyone else feels the same way and how they cope with it. I'm also wondering if moving away for grad school is that much better if there weren't a pandemic shutting everything down/limiting any social activities; especially since so many people refer to grad school as an isolating experience anyway.

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! I'm glad you're here. Feel free to share whatever's on your mind or any concerns you might have.
Hey, thanks for having me. Lately, I've been struggling with the transition back to in-person learning and feeling pretty lonely in a new city. It's been hard to adjust and focus on my studies.
It sounds like you're facing a lot of challenges right now with adjusting to a new environment. How do you envision things being different if these changes you’re considering were to happen?

I guess if things were different, I'd feel more connected and settled, like I did at home. I'd have a better balance between school and social life which would help me focus more on my studies without feeling so isolated.
therapist: Finding that balance and sense of connection seems really important to you. What small steps do you think could help you move towards feeling more settled and connected?
client: I think reaching out to classmates more might help, even if it's just virtual chats for now. Maybe exploring the city a bit on my own could also make it feel less foreign and more like home.

Therapist: Those sound like thoughtful steps toward feeling more connected and settled. Based on what you said, possible options could include setting a goal to connect with classmates virtually each week or planning a weekly outing to explore a new part of the city. How do these options feel for you, and what barriers might you anticipate as you start?

I think those ideas sound doable, and I could definitely try to set up some virtual coffee breaks with classmates. The biggest barrier is probably just feeling awkward or worried about how they'll respond, especially since people are so cautious right now. Exploring the city alone might be challenging too, given the pandemic restrictions and just not knowing where to start.

It sounds like you're really giving this a lot of thought, which is a big step forward. Setting up virtual coffee breaks with classmates and planning some solo city explorations are great ways to start feeling more at home. It's understandable to feel awkward or worried about responses—many people feel that way when reaching out. Remember, it's okay to take things at your own pace. Perhaps you could start with small, manageable steps, like exploring a nearby park or sending a brief message to a classmate you feel comfortable with. 

You've already identified some solid coping strategies, and I believe you can navigate these barriers by taking gradual steps. Each effort, no matter how small, is a step in the right direction. For the next week, maybe you could focus on connecting with one classmate and exploring one new area. How does that sound for a starting plan? Remember, I'm here to support you as you take these steps, and you're not alone in this journey.
Yeah, I think starting small like that could work. I'll try to reach out to someone and maybe check out a park nearby.

concern: I have never been in an academic setting that challenged me so much. In undergrad I was always on top of my work and had enough time to enjoy myself, go to the gym, and even party. In my second year of my PhD program all I do is work and on the weekends I usually sleep or go out somewhere just to try to enjoy myself. Now that the semester has begun I lost my Sundays to a full day of class work. I am so lucky to do what I love, but I love it a lot less when I am being overworked. It does not help that my PI is an absolute workaholic. How do people not burn out working 6 days a week with such mentally involved tasks?

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! It's great to have you here. What's been on your mind lately that you'd like to talk about?
I've been feeling pretty overwhelmed with my PhD program lately. It's like there's no time for anything but work, and it's starting to wear me down.
It sounds like your PhD program is really consuming a lot of your energy and time. How do you feel this is affecting other areas of your life right now?
Honestly, it's like everything else is taking a backseat. I'm not spending as much time on things that used to make me happy or relaxed, and it's frustrating.

It seems like you're really missing those activities that used to bring you joy and relaxation. What do you think life would look like if you managed to find a better balance between your work and those other areas?
I think I'd feel a lot more like myself again, you know? I'd have more energy, more joy, and probably be a lot less stressed if I could fit in time for the things I enjoy.
That sounds like a wonderful vision of balance and fulfillment. On a scale from 0 to 10, how confident do you feel about making some changes to achieve that sense of self again?
I’d say maybe a 5 or 6? It feels like there’s room to make changes, but I’m not entirely sure where to start or how to manage everything without slipping up.
It's great that you see some potential for change, even if the path isn't entirely clear yet. What small steps do you think could move you closer to that balance and fulfillment you're envisioning?

I guess maybe setting some boundaries with my work time would be a start, like making sure I have a cut-off time in the evening. Also, trying to bring back some activities I used to enjoy, even if it's just a little bit each week, might help too.
Those sound like thoughtful and manageable steps. How do you imagine your life might change if you started setting those boundaries and reintroducing activities you love?
I think I'd feel a lot more like myself again, you know? I'd have more energy, more joy, and probably be a lot less stressed if I could fit in time for the things I enjoy.

It sounds like setting boundaries and reintroducing enjoyable activities could really enhance your well-being. Based on what you’ve shared, possible options could include setting a specific evening cut-off time for work or choosing one activity to reintroduce into your routine each week. What goal would you like to set, and what first step do you feel ready to take?
I think setting a specific cut-off time for work would be a good place to start. Maybe I’ll aim to stop working by 7 PM every night and see how that goes.

That sounds like a great first step towards creating more balance. How do you plan to ensure you stick to the 7 PM cut-off time, and what might you do if you encounter challenges sticking to this goal?

I guess I'll try setting an alarm or reminder on my phone as a prompt to stop work. If I run into challenges, like feeling the need to finish something urgent, I might need to prioritize tasks better or adjust my schedule for the next day.

You've really thought this through, and your plan to set a 7 PM work cut-off time with phone reminders sounds like a solid step towards finding balance. Prioritizing tasks and being flexible with your schedule can be a great way to handle any unexpected challenges. It's encouraging to hear you're open to adjusting things if needed. Remember, it's about progress, not perfection. As you move forward, be kind to yourself and celebrate the small wins. If you find yourself needing extra support, feel free to reach out. You've got a thoughtful plan, and I believe in your ability to make these changes. Looking forward to hearing how it's going for you.
Thanks, I appreciate your support and advice. I’ll definitely keep you posted on how it's going.

concern:
Will be having my Master's Thesis proposal defense in the morning, and I'm all a bit tense and anxious and nervous and all the things that have going through my head. 

Been sleepy all day as if this is a way for me to cope with the stress it causes. Wish me luck everyone, good luck also to the countless graduate students who will be defending their own works!


Update: 

I cant believe it's done! I passed the proposal defence. Now I cant rest for a week from .

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! It's great to have you here today. Whenever you're ready, feel free to share what's on your mind or anything you'd like to talk about.
Honestly, I'm just relieved right now. I had my Master's thesis proposal defense, and the stress leading up to it was intense. I'm just trying to process it all and figure out how to unwind.

{"reasoning":"The client has shared a significant event and its emotional impact, revealing stress and relief post-defense. However, more exploration is needed to fully understand their feelings, coping mechanisms, and stress management before moving to the Guiding phase.","determination":"continue"}
It sounds like you went through a lot leading up to your thesis defense. You feel relieved because the pressure is finally off. How are you thinking about unwinding and taking care of yourself now?

client: I think I just need to give myself permission to do nothing for a bit, maybe watch some shows or hang out with friends without worrying about deadlines. I want to recharge and not think about school work for a few days.

That sounds like a really healthy way to recharge and give yourself a break. Allowing yourself some downtime to enjoy shows or spend time with friends can be a great way to unwind. How does it feel to consider this time for yourself without the pressure of deadlines?

client: It feels kind of freeing, honestly. Like I can finally breathe without the weight of deadlines constantly looming over me. But there's also this weird feeling of guilt, like I should be doing something productive, even though I know I need the break.

It's understandable to feel a mix of freedom and guilt when taking time for yourself. You recognize the importance of downtime, yet the urge to stay productive is strong. What do you think it would look like if you allowed yourself to fully embrace this break without guilt?

I guess it would mean fully letting myself relax and just enjoy the moment without checking emails or thinking about school stuff. Maybe doing things purely for fun, like picking up a hobby I've neglected or trying something new, and reminding myself that it's okay to rest and recharge.

It's great that you're considering ways to embrace your break and enjoy the moment. Based on what you've mentioned, possible options could include setting a specific timeframe to unplug from school-related activities and exploring those hobbies you've been interested in. How do you feel about creating a plan to incorporate these activities and truly allow yourself to relax?

I think having a plan could really help me feel more intentional about taking a break. Setting a timeframe to unplug sounds like a good way to give myself permission to really step away from school stuff. I just need to make sure I actually stick to it and don't let the guilt creep back in.

You've really explored the idea of taking intentional time for yourself, and it's wonderful to see you recognizing the value in that. You've mentioned setting a specific timeframe to unplug, which sounds like a sensible approach to ensure you can relax and recharge fully. Remember, it's okay to enjoy downtime and pursue hobbies purely for your enjoyment. Embrace that freedom—it’s a key part of maintaining a balanced life.

As you move forward, consider starting with just a small amount of time each day or week dedicated solely to activities that bring you joy and relaxation. It's perfectly normal to feel some guilt at first, but remind yourself that rest is productive too. This plan can serve as your personal permission slip to take breaks without any second thoughts.

Keep in touch with how you’re feeling throughout this process—self-awareness is powerful. If you find that the guilt returns, reflect on your progress and remind yourself of the importance of recharging. You're doing a great job acknowledging your needs, and with each step you take, you're fostering a healthier balance. Take it one day at a time, and trust that you're on the right track.

Yeah, I think starting small will definitely make it feel more doable, and I'll try to remind myself that rest is just as important as work. I just hope I don't end up feeling guilty like I usually do.

concern:
Not sure if anyone else feels this way but it can be a lonely journey in grad school especially because of the niche stresses, things we have to deal with. 

Created a group me that will hopefully foster some community for people to talk with one another and build some friendships or the very least camaraderie 

Here’s the link to join: You're invited to my new group 'Grad School Community' on GroupMe. Click here to join: https://groupme.com/join_group/86601776/iTupsbUn

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! It's great to see you today. Whenever you're ready, feel free to share what's on your mind or any concerns you might have.
Hey, thanks. I've just been feeling pretty isolated lately, you know? Grad school has its own set of challenges that not everyone gets, and it's tough not having people to really share that with.
therapist: It sounds like grad school is quite challenging, and you're feeling the weight of going through it alone. How do you think your life might be different if you had more support?

client: I think having more support would make a big difference. Just having people to talk to who understand what I'm going through would be really comforting, and maybe it would help me not feel so overwhelmed all the time.

Therapist: It seems like finding support is really important to you. Based on what you've shared, we could explore options like joining a study group or seeking out student social events. Which of these, or perhaps another idea, do you feel might be a good first step for you?

Yeah, joining something like a study group could help, but I think I was looking for more of a casual space where people just get it, you know? That's why I started that GroupMe chat, to hopefully create a place where we can all just connect and share experiences without any pressure.

Starting that GroupMe chat sounds like a great way to create a casual and supportive space, and it's wonderful that you've taken initiative to connect with others who understand your experience. It shows your commitment to fostering a sense of community, which can be so beneficial. As you continue nurturing this space, consider setting small goals, like planning virtual meet-ups or sharing resources that might strengthen those connections. Remember, it's okay to reach out and let others know how they can support you too. Keep going with this effort, and let’s plan to check in on how it’s unfolding during our next session.
Thanks for the encouragement. I'll definitely think about setting some goals for the group and see how it goes. I'll keep you updated next time we meet.

concern:
I graduated college less than a year ago (May 2022); and my undergraduate experience was already screwed up by COVID-19 - I was forced to skip out on a full year before returning to Senior year because the US did not allow international students to take hybrid classes and my university was not offering at least 3 in-person classes for me during the 2020 - 2021 lockdown. So I got to watch all my friends graduate without me; I did qualify for an accelerated Master's Program in Economics and I was accepted but I opted not to pursue it due to COVID-19 and feeling that I did not want to stay in Fordham for both undergraduate and graduate school.  


Anyway, I somehow managed to get a short-term contract at the World Bank since they hired people from around the world, and if I work for the World Bank in a full-time job for about 15 years I am eligible for permanent residency (green card). For all intents and purposes I really want to stay and live and build a life in the US (especially now with geopolitical events in SE Asia). The problem is that I don't have options for employment in the private sector because the H1-b process is absurdly random and difficult; and the World Bank and IMF have outright told me that I can't get a fulltime job without AT LEAST a Master's Degree (it's already brutally difficult for me to get even a short-term contract role, let alone a fulltime job); and even this employment is not guaranteed.  


I'm thinking of getting a Master's Degree in Statistics or Data Science (an MBA or Master's degree in economics isn't very helpful) but I have checked that I did not take enough undergrad courses in Math or Computer Science to qualify (at least in the US). I'm fairly certain that my math skills and coding skills are nowhere near good enough for grad school (I struggled for a 3.60 gpa even before COVID-19)  
I'm honestly totally lost because I'm being forced to prepare for grad school so soon, just after I managed to find something solid career-wise (I'm 23 turning 24). Otherwise I have to go back to the Philippines and I probably won't have an opportunity to immigrate elsewhere anymore.  


Any advice for my circumstances?

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! It's great to see you. Whenever you're ready, feel free to share what's on your mind or any concerns you might have.
Hey, thanks. I'm just feeling a bit overwhelmed with everything. Trying to figure out how to stay in the US and what to do next with my career is really stressing me out.
therapist: It sounds like you're facing some big decisions right now. What would staying in the US and moving forward in your career mean for you?
client: Staying here means a lot. It’s about the opportunities, safety, and the chance to build a life I want. Moving forward in my career would give me stability and a sense of accomplishment.
therapist: It sounds like both staying in the US and advancing in your career are really important to you. What are some steps you think you might take to start moving towards that life you envision?
client: Honestly, I'm trying to explore getting a Master's degree, maybe in Statistics or Data Science. But I'm worried about not meeting the requirements and if it's even the right move for me.
therapist: It seems like you're considering some significant steps with the Master's degree. What are the aspects of Statistics or Data Science that draw you towards them?

client: I think it's the practicality and demand for those skills. I've heard there's a lot of job opportunities in those fields, and they seem like they'd give me a solid foundation to build a career on. Plus, it feels like a way to keep my options open.
It sounds like you're drawn to the practicality and potential opportunities these fields offer. What might it feel like to achieve that solid foundation and keep your options open?

client: I think it would feel reassuring, like I have a safety net and more control over my future. It would probably give me some confidence too, knowing I have skills that are in demand and can lead to a stable career.

That's a very thoughtful reflection on how achieving this could impact your life. Given your interest in pursuing a Master's degree, perhaps we can explore specific actions to help you move forward. Options could involve researching programs that align with your interests or connecting with professionals in the field for insights. What might be your first step towards this goal?

I guess starting with researching programs would be a good first step. I need to figure out which ones fit my background and what prerequisites I'd need to meet. Maybe I can also try to reach out to some people who are already in the field.

It sounds like you've laid out some clear steps to take as you move forward—starting with researching programs and reaching out to professionals in the field. Your focus on building a solid foundation with a practical skill set is inspiring. Remember, it's okay to take things one step at a time and allow yourself to explore your options thoroughly. As you begin this process, think about leaning on your support system, whether it's friends, mentors, or colleagues, to help guide you along the way. You're making informed and empowered choices, and that's something to be proud of. If you ever feel overwhelmed, remember you’re not alone in this journey, and support is always available. Keep believing in yourself, and take each day as a new opportunity. Your first step towards researching programs is a strong start, and I'm confident you'll navigate this path with the same thoughtfulness you've shown today.
Thanks for the encouragement. I'm a bit nervous about starting this process, but I'll try to take it one step at a time like you said.

client: client: Honestly, I'm trying to explore getting a Master's degree, maybe in Statistics or Data Science. But I'm worried about not meeting the requirements and if it's even the right move for me.
therapist: therapist: It seems like you're considering some significant steps with the Master's degree. What are the aspects of Statistics or Data Science that draw you towards them?
client: client: I think it's the practicality and demand for those skills. I've heard there's a lot of job opportunities in those fields, and they seem like they'd give me a solid foundation to build a career on. Plus, it feels like a way to keep my options open.
therapist: It sounds like you're drawn to the practicality and potential opportunities these fields offer. What might it feel like to achieve that solid foundation and keep your options open?
client: client: I think it would feel reassuring, like I have a safety net and more control over my future. It would probably give me some confidence too, knowing I have skills that are in demand and can lead to a stable career.
therapist: That's a very thoughtful reflection on how achieving this could impact your life. Given your interest in pursuing a Master's degree, perhaps we can explore specific actions to help you move forward. Options could involve researching programs that align with your interests or connecting with professionals in the field for insights. What might be your first step towards this goal?
client: I guess starting with researching programs would be a good first step. I need to figure out which ones fit my background and what prerequisites I'd need to meet. Maybe I can also try to reach out to some people who are already in the field.
therapist: It sounds like you've laid out some clear steps to take as you move forward—starting with researching programs and reaching out to professionals in the field. Your focus on building a solid foundation with a practical skill set is inspiring. Remember, it's okay to take things one step at a time and allow yourself to explore your options thoroughly. As you begin this process, think about leaning on your support system, whether it's friends, mentors, or colleagues, to help guide you along the way. You're making informed and empowered choices, and that's something to be proud of. If you ever feel overwhelmed, remember you’re not alone in this journey, and support is always available. Keep believing in yourself, and take each day as a new opportunity. Your first step towards researching programs is a strong start, and I'm confident you'll navigate this path with the same thoughtfulness you've shown today.
client: Thanks for the encouragement. I'm a bit nervous about starting this process, but I'll try to take it one step at a time like you said.
